bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, September 1, 1890

div1.p: Lazear writes about visiting Heidelberg, Frankfort, and the Rhine River valley.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, September 1, 1890
div1.p:
Here we are at
a small town about six miles
below Koblentz on the Rhine.

We remained at Heidelberg
until Friday morning or nearly two
days. On Thursday I went to the
Castle and to the summit of the
Konigstuhl a high mountain
near the town from which I had
a magnificent view. Heidelberg
itself is a very interesting town
but overrun with tourists.
I was very much tempted by
the display of Meerschaum pipes in
the windows but I did not yield
to the temptation as they were all
expensive. On Friday we went to
Frankfort-on-the-Main where we
remained until noon on Saturday
Frankfort is really a very beautiful
city. There is a good at art gallery
there which we visited. We also
went to the magnificent Opera House
where we heard the last half
of the G“otterda“mmerung. It was
very well sung and I really enjoyed
it very much although it is, as
you know, one of Wagner's heaviest
operas. We saw the Rothschild
house in Frankfort. From there we
went to Wiesbaden. We walked
around here in Wiesbaden for
about an hour and then
started on our walk down the
Rhine. We stayed that night at
Erbach. The shore in that area
vicinity is lined with handsome
villas. The next day we walked
as far as St. Goorshousen passing
the most magnificent scenery.
We saw the famous Johannesberg
vineyards. At R“udesheim we climbed
up in the hills of the Niederwald where
we saw the great German memorial
statue commemorating in memory
of the war of 70 & 71. From this point
the view is very fine. L Immediately
opposite is the town of Bingen. Today
the scenery has been very fine but
hardly up to yesterday's. Tomorrow
we will reach try to reach Bonn
and we will get to Cologne early
on Wednesday. From there we
will go by rail to Amsterdam
on Thursday. On Saturday morning
we sail for home. The boat that
we take is very slow and she will
not get to New York before the 20th
of September. I will telegraph
to you as soon as we reach
New York.

I am now in good walking
condition. In the last two days we
have walked over Sixty-five miles
and tomorrow we expect to do
thirty-seven.

I will write to you again in
Amsterdam before we start and
you will get the letter several
days before we arrive.
